Okay. So, for those that don't know, Jet
Brains has a CI/CD solution called Team
City. It's been around for a number of
years, and about a year ago, we released
a plug-in for Team City that enables
integration with Unreal Engine. And what
this offers is a dedicated Unreal Engine
build step, which I'll show in a moment.
Also integration with Unreal Game Sync,
so UGS metadata server. Automatic engine
detection, so it detects all the
different versions of Unreal on the
build machines. Automatic test
reporting, so when you're running your
Unreal tests, the test results are
automatically passed and shown in Team
City, and you can then view the trends
over time. We do also have native
Perforce support, so ideal for uh Unreal
projects. But the most powerful feature
is the distributed build graph support.
And I'll show this in a moment. And this
allows you to pass the build graph
script, your XML build graph file, and
distribute all of the jobs across all
available build nodes to significantly
speed up the time it takes to run the
pipeline.
So we have uh integration with UAT and
you can do uh standard build cook run
configurations. There's also support for
commandlets running uh distributed
builds with buildg graph. As I mentioned
we have perforce support as well as git
and you can easily define your pipeline.
So let's look at a real world example.
So this is team city. I've got the Lyra
project here and inside of here I've got
a configuration called CI. I've run a
few of these builds recently and I'll
just kick another one off now. We can
see this in progress in a moment. What
will happen first of all is it will pass
the build graph script because I've
enabled build graph for this project.
Um, and then we'll get an automatically
generated pipeline. While that's
generating, I'll show a previous one
that's already finished. And we can see
here the autogenerated pipeline. So
we're building the editor and tools for
Windows and Linux. And we eventually
cook and compile for those different
platforms and package. And this is also
generating artifacts that are stored
inside of team city. So this visual this
nice visual representation of the
pipeline is given to us just through
virtue of having that build graph script
inside of our project. We can view all
of these jobs in a list form. So we can
see them all here. We can see the agent
that it was executed on, the time it was
executed, the status, also the test
results. And for any jobs that do have
artifacts associated with them, we can
see those just by hovering over the
artifact icon.
So let's go back here and we'll look at
this one that's now running. And if we
go to the chain view, we can see that
this is running on our uh build agents.
And this is like a a good visualization
to see where you're at in your project
run.
And if I go over to Ryder, we'll look at
the build graph script. And what team

agent node inside of my XML file, I'm
converting this into a dynamic job. And
for every node inside of this, I'm
converting that into a build step. So
for the agent, we are um iterating over
the different platforms that are passed
in. So if I go to the configuration
for this project,
we have the Unreal Engine build step
and we've got the option here to choose

you can see there are the other options
on here also

passing in the plus separated values. So
for editor platforms we're building for
Linux and wind 64 and that's what we are
iterating over here. So for each of
those platforms, we are creating dynamic
jobs for each of those platforms with
these three steps within it.
Um we can see the option here. So
distributed builds. So this is this is
what gives you the most value of running
your pipeline in team city. If you chose
single machine, the whole build is run
on a single machine, hence the name.
with distributed. That's what passes the
uh buildgraph script and runs it across
all of the available nodes.

And I've got two self-hosted agents for

agents or build machines that are
running on AWS EC2. They are static
instances. But we do have the option in
Team City to define what we call a cloud
profile.
And a cloud profile enables Team City to
spin up build machines on demand.
So on the cloud profile screen here, we
can create a new profile and choose for
example AWS EC2. Once we've defined our
settings and chosen the region we want
to use, Team City will fetch a list of
AMIs and existing instances on that AWS
account and it can resume and suspend
those on demand as well as create new
instances as and when builds are added
to the queue. So, it's a great way to
scale up dynamically. And we do also
have spot instance support uh inside of
this configuration.
Going back to the agent screen, the way
that Team City knows how to split the
jobs from the build graph file across
the different nodes is done through the

Unreal, if I can type properly,
and we've got here a parameter called
buildgraph.agent.type.
And this is a list of separated values
that define the jobs that this can take.
Um so that's how it knows how to
distribute the different jobs across the
uh the build graph script.
We can also see the build history on

And then one final thing to show as

So as well as the build step screen,
we've got the option here for defining
triggers. So this can help you to
automatically trigger your build based
on various conditions. The most common
would be a VCS trigger. So whenever a
commit is made to your repository or
your Perforce uh depot, you can
automatically trigger a new build. We've
got schedule trigger. Uh, also if you
want to do like a retry build if
something fails for some reason.
And then lastly, we've got the build
features screen and this enables you to
complement the job with additional
features. For example, if you want to
gate the build processor tool, we have a
build approval feature where we could
say I want user Alexi to approve this or
also the user group project admins and
at least like three users from that
group. So, it's a great way to add an
approval process if you're doing
deployments.
And then a bunch of other features for
things like build caching if you want to
cache certain dependencies on the server
between builds if you are using
single-use agents.
The commit status publisher. This helps
you to to publish the status of your
commits to external uh sources. So for
example, we could choose the Perforce
VCS route and then come in here and
choose the UGS metadata server option to
define the settings for that connection.
Um, other options include things like
checking for free disk space if you are
using reusable agents and you want to
ensure that a certain amount of space is
available on that agent before the build
starts rather than wait for the build to
go through and then it uh breaks because
of a lack of space.
We have things like matrix build for
running the same build multiple times on
different platforms. For example, I
could uh define a platform parameter
and give it two different values like
Windows and Linux.
And what will happen is the same
configuration will be run twice once for
Windows once for Linux. And this avoids
duplicating your entire job definitions.
This is another way to do reusable
builds inside of Team City.
Uh, one of the final features is
notifications. So, you can do Slack
notifications if needed as well as email
notifications
and things like parallel testing. So,
you can split your tests up across
different nodes.
And that's pretty much everything from
